I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  2007  Country  Programming  Mission,  the  Government  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to assist the Qinghai 
Provincial Department of Water Resources (QDOWR) to prepare the Qinghai Rural Water 
Resources Management Project, which is included in the PRC’s country partnership strategy 
(2008–2010).1 ADB  fielded  a  Fact-Finding  Mission  in  March  2008  for  formulating  project 
preparatory technical assistance. The Mission visited the project area; held discussions with 
government representatives from the central, provincial, county, and prefecture levels, as well 
as  with  development  partners  and  beneficiaries;  and  reached  preliminary  agreements  and 
understandings on the impact, outcome, implementation arrangements, cost estimates, and 
consultant’s terms of reference for the technical assistance (TA).2 The TA design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Rural Poverty and Irrigation. The PRC has developed rapidly during the last nearly 
three decades, with its economy growing by approximately 9% per annum.3 In spite of this 
growth, however, the PRC continues to be a lower middle income country with a sizeable 
number of poor living on less than $1 a day. Low farm productivity, poor rural infrastructure, lack 
of access to rural finance, poor education and skills, and other constraints limit economic 
opportunities for the rural poor and leave them vulnerable to economic and social risks.  
 
3.  Despite the PRC’s strong and sustained economic growth, poverty is still widespread,  
especially in remote rural areas in the western regions. Most of the rural poor lack adequate 
access to social services, including health care, education, water supply, and sanitation. The 
basic factors causing poverty in rural areas are (i) heavy dependence on subsistence agriculture, 
(ii) inadequate physical infrastructure and human capital, (iii) insufficient government capacity, 
and (iv) lack of employment opportunities. Income inequalities between eastern and western 
PRC  have  risen,  and  the  income  gap  between  rural  and  urban  households  has  widened 
considerably since the late 1970s. Urban incomes are now more than three times higher than 
rural  incomes.  The  Government  is  taking  measures  to  correct  this  trend  by  increasing 
investments in rural areas, especially in rural infrastructure, education, and health. Similarly, 
high  priority  has  been  accorded  to  pro-poor  growth  in  rural  areas  through  aggressive 
investments  into  agriculture  and  rural  infrastructure,  including  irrigation.  Reducing  poverty 
remains a daunting challenge, however, as does raising the welfare of millions living just above 
poverty. To meet this challenge, it will be vital to sustain growth while addressing environmental 
degradation, growing inequality, and the strain on resources. The initial poverty and social 
analysis is in Appendix 2. 
 
4.  Irrigation and water management is essential to sustainable agriculture throughout the 
year in most regions of the PRC. Meeting irrigation needs has become one of the major issues 
within the water sector. Irrigation represented 63.2% of total water use in 2006, a decrease from 
68.8% in 2000 due to the PRC’s rapid urbanization, economic growth, and population growth. At 
the same time, per capita water availability is rapidly declining as ecological and water stress is 
increasing in many river basins. These combined factors have highlighted the need for more 
efficient  and  sustainable  water  resources  management,  particularly  for  the  purpose  of

increasing the irrigation water coefficient in order to meet the rising requirements of irrigation

5.  The  Government  has  revised  the  National  Water  Policy  periodically  since  1998  to 
address these challenges, promoting state level policy and institutional reforms to (i) manage 
water efficiently using integrated water resources management (IWRM), and (ii) pursue higher 
system utilization and sustainable operation and maintenance (O&M) with participatory irrigation 
management (PIM). These changes were further stipulated in the revised 2002 National Water 
Law. While considerable progress has been made to implement PIM and IWRM, the process is 
still in a formative stage. Also, provincial agencies are unable to deliver services with adequate 
participation from farmers. 
 
6.  Rural Economy and Agriculture in Qinghai. Qinghai is located in the Upper Yangtze 
and Yellow River valleys in the northeastern part of the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau. It is classified 
as a food deficit province, importing about 350,000 tons of grain annually. It is further classified 
as the second poorest province in the PRC. The province’s relatively small population of 5.38 
million is distributed over a large area covering 720,000 square kilometers, of which 20% is 
urban and 80% is rural. The bulk of the rural population is concentrated in farming areas in the 
eastern region, which makes up only 5% of the province’s total land area but feeds about 75% 
of its total population. Of the total population in the project area, 42.8% comprise ethnic minority 
groups (Tibetan, Hui, and Sala). The per capita net income and consumption expenditure of 
farmers in Qinghai in 2004 has been about two thirds of the national average.4 
 
7.  To  enhance  agricultural  productivity,  Qinghai  Province  has  introduced  policies  to 
increase cropping intensity and diversity through improved water management, input distribution, 
extension systems, and infrastructure. The agricultural tax has been lifted, and although there 
are still bottlenecks in extension systems, sporadic positive developments are evident in many 
places, and specifically where irrigation is assured along with good connectivity to markets. To 
improve agriculture, concerted efforts are needed to (i) identify suitable area-specific farming 
systems by analyzing local production, marketing conditions, and farmer incentives; (ii) set 
realistic output targets; and (iii) define programs to address local constraints while meeting the 
specific needs of the poor. 
 
8.  Status of Irrigation and Water Resources. The project area is in eastern Qinghai and 
is served by two main irrigation schemes in the valley of the Yellow River. The Lijiaxia and 
Gongboxia irrigation schemes collectively cover the project counties of Hualong, Jianza, and 
Xunhua. The existing schemes were built in the early 1970s and were designed to operate 
through lift irrigation. In recent times, however, rising electricity, water, and agricultural input 
costs have been a major constraint on increased agricultural production. Many fertile upland 
agricultural lands lay fallow due to the rising costs of lift irrigation. The pumping stations have 
fallen into disrepair as a result of limited usage, and farmers are forced to find alternative 
sources of income (such as daily manual labor in the construction industry). Farming under 
these conditions is no longer economically-feasible. 
 
9.  Policy and Institutional Level. With the support of other development partners, the 
policy  and  institutional  environment  surrounding  water  resources  management  has  seen 
progressive improvements in the last decade. In particular, (i) water policies and plans are in 
place that have adopted key principles of PIM and IWRM, (ii) legislation has led to creating a 
water users association (WUA) framework to implement PIM, (iii) the principle of full O&M

3
financing by beneficiaries has been adopted, and (iv) steps toward establishing institutions and 
functions for IWRM have been initiated on the basis of river basins. Although QDOWR has been 
strengthened in accordance with national policies, there is still much progress to be made and it 
should be noted that implementation of many of these reforms is still at an early stage. 
 
10.  Irrigation Service Delivery. The province has initiated steps to transfer minor irrigation 
canal management to WUAs, subject to (i) WUA formation, (ii) establishment of an irrigation 
service charge, and (iii) introduction of prerequisites (e.g., training) to initiate O&M by WUAs for 
the transferred canals. Progress has been hampered, however, by the inability of WUAs to 
perform the required O&M work on their own. QDOWR and WUAs have still not reached an 
adequate  level  of  development  enabling  them  to  adequately  support  accountable  service 
delivery  and  O&M  cost  recovery.  There  presently  exists  a  vicious  cycle  of  low  irrigation 
performance and ad hoc collection of service charges that contributes to even lower overall 
irrigation performance. WUAs need strengthening for effective transfer of responsibilities. There 
is significant support for PIM, and QDOWR has established a good foundation. Still, QDOWR 
needs to strengthen its analytical capacities to design and plan irrigation projects. 
 
11.  IWRM. In recognition of increasing competition for water, there is a need to further 
operationalize specific IWRM functions, including (i) participatory and holistic basin planning that 
incorporates  water  investments,  watershed  management,  agriculture,  and  other  support 
services; and (ii) the introduction of regulatory functions for water use and quality management.  
 
12.  Opportunities for ADB Support. The TA and ensuing investment project will support 
the country partnership strategy (2008–2010), the Government’s pro-poor economic growth 
strategy, and the Government’s 11th Five-Year Plan (2006–2010) by helping the rural poor boost 
productivity  and  diversify  production  while  stimulating  off-farm  activity  through  rural 
infrastructure such as irrigation. It will do so by (i) expanding access to sustainable irrigation 
through command area development and water resources management, (ii) strengthening farm-
to-market linkages, and (iii) improving the enabling environment for agribusiness with particular 
emphasis  on  initiatives  by  women  and  disadvantaged  groups  by  strengthening  community 
empowerment. 
 
13.  In this context, QDOWR has requested ADB’s support for irrigation infrastructure and 
agricultural  development  covering  physical  infrastructure  works  to  construct  four  irrigation 
canals based on the already established outlets on the left and right dam shoulders in order to 
serve the water requirements to the farming communities flanked on either side. Because this 
will have the effect of converting the existing lift irrigation schemes to provide gravity irrigation 
for agricultural needs, an intervention proposal will be prepared. This proposal needs to show 
high returns and revenues while at the same time strengthening and operationalizing the policy 
and institutional framework for PIM and IWRM. The TA will support this process by assessing 
the most effective way of addressing the aforementioned issues. It is also consistent with ADB’s 
water policy, which advocates a participatory approach to help conserve and protect water 
resources and foster integrated water resources management. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
14.  The expected impact of the TA will be rehabilitated and newly constructed key water 
resources infrastructure in the three participating counties of Qinghai Province. The TA outcome 
will be a project design agreed by QDOWR, the Government, and ADB that will (i) enhance

4   
productivity and sustainability of existing irrigation systems with increased provincial revenues; 
and (ii) strengthen institutions, including QDOWR in delivering accountable irrigation services, 
WUAs in fulfilling specified O&M tasks, and other agencies in providing sound support services. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  The TA will have three specific outputs for the project area: (i) an irrigated agriculture 
strategy and action plan, (ii) an institutional development strategy for PIM and IWRM with a 
program of capacity building and project management, and (iii) an investment proposal that 
meets ADB’s safeguards and other requirements.  
 
16.  The TA will utilize (i) detailed subproject feasibility study reports prepared by QDOWR; (ii) 
existing policy, planning, and institutional documents; and (iii) other information relating to the 
sector. Building on this information, the TA will carefully analyze local conditions while applying 
lessons and best practices learned in the PRC and other countries. A participatory approach will 
be undertaken during project preparation. It will include workshops and focus group meetings 
with key stakeholders—including representatives of poor communities—in order to address their 
needs. In line with each output, TA activities will include: 
 
(i)  Initial assessments. The TA will provide support to conduct a baseline survey 
covering social, poverty, and institutional capacity, and it will take into account 
lessons learned from similar ADB,5 World Bank, and other donor-funded projects. 
Based on the initial survey work, the TA will prepare (a) a preliminary project 
design  and  monitoring  framework;  (b)  safeguards  frameworks  (incorporating 
resettlement,  land  acquisition,  environment,  and  indigenous  peoples);  (c)  a 
project implementation framework; and (d) an irrigated agriculture development 
strategy with updated irrigation interventions. 
(ii)  Subcomponent proposal development. The subcomponent proposals will be 
reviewed and revised based on the baseline surveys, stakeholder consultations, 
and the irrigated agriculture development strategy to define specific components 
for irrigation, agriculture, and associated services in accordance with the holistic 
strategy outlined above. The TA will also help prepare a detailed institutional 
development action plan. 
(iii)  Development of an investment proposal. The consultant team will prepare a 
comprehensive feasibility report covering (a) project impact, outcome, outputs, 
and  activities;  (b)  technical,  financial,  economic,  and  social  analyses  and 
preparation of social and environment safeguard documents; (c) relevant sector 
and  problem  analyses;  (d)  roles  and  institutional  capacities  of  participating 
agencies; (e) implementation arrangements; and (f) interrelated issues of poverty 
reduction,  gender  equality,  good  governance,  and  possible  private  sector 
development. In order to create a strong sense of ownership, investment plans 
must be (a) consistent with government strategies and plans, and (b) endorsed 
by the key stakeholders (including the project beneficiaries). 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $875,000 equivalent, of which $700,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program and administered by ADB. QDOWR will

Information System (EVIS): http://evis.adb.org.

5
finance the remaining $175,000 equivalent for office space, counterpart staff, data analyses 
(including feasibility study reports), and other administrative costs. The Government has been 
informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. The 
detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  QDOWR will be the Executing Agency for the TA. It will appoint a full-time technical 
director at the level of chief engineer to support the project preparation. To guide TA activities, 
QDOWR will also form a project steering committee. Chaired by QDOWR’s director general, the 
committee  will  include  specialists  in  agriculture,  watershed  management,  and  forestry 
nominated  by  the  departments  concerned.  At  the  outset,  QDOWR  will  provide  (i)  detailed 
feasibility reports to be studied in detail under the TA, (ii) irrigation scheme inventories, (iii) 
support for baseline surveys and materials related to the sector and its policy and institutional 
framework, and (iv) assistance to the consultant team to organize meetings and workshops. 
 
19.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  over  a  period  of  6  months  from  September  2008  to 
February  2009.  It  will  require  15  person-months  of  international  and  24  person-months  of 
national consultants covering irrigation planning and management, irrigation institutions, PIM, 
IWRM,  agronomy,  agriculture,  economics,  sociology,  environment,  and  resettlement.  It  will 
include studies, surveys, and consultations. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in 
Appendix  4.  ADB  will  recruit  an  international  consulting  firm  in  association  with  national 
consultants following ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time 
to  time)  and  other  arrangements  acceptable  to  ADB  for  engaging  national  consultants 
satisfactory to ADB. The simplified technical proposal procedure will be followed, along with 
quality and cost-based selection at a quality:cost ratio of 80:20. The consultants will submit an 
inception report within 1 month, a midterm report within 4 months, and a draft final report within 
6  months.  Tripartite  meetings  between  Qinghai  provincial  government,  ADB,  and  the 
consultants will be held to discuss these reports, which also will be presented in workshops with 
relevant stakeholders. A final report will be submitted within 2 weeks after the Government, 
Qinghai provincial government, and ADB comment on the draft final report. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for preparing the Qinghai Rural Water 
Resources Management Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
 
Country/Project Title:  People’s Republic of China/Preparing the Qinghai Rural Water Resources Management Project 
 
Lending/Financing  Project  Department/  East Asia Department/

I.  POVERTY ISSUES 
 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategya 
 
1.  Based on the country poverty assessment, the country partnership strategy (CPS) and the sector analysis, describe 
how the project would directly or indirectly contribute to poverty reduction and how it is linked to the poverty reduction strategy 
of the partner country. 
 
During the 10th Five-Year Plan (2001–2005), the People’s Republic of China (PRC) made remarkable progress in reducing 
poverty, with the number of rural poor falling from about 250 million in 1978 to 85 million in 1990 and 23.7 million in 2005. The 
population below the international standard of $1 per day (using purchasing power parity) fell from 374.8 million (33% of the 
population) in 1990 to 135 million (10% of the population) in 2005. Several non-income aspects of poverty have also improved, 
with the PRC poised to achieve Millennium Development Goal (MDG) targets for maternal health and primary education. More 
targeted and innovative approaches are needed to address (i) persistent absolute poverty, increasingly concentrated in hard-
to-reach groups (e.g., remote communities, the elderly, and disabled); (ii) the vulnerability of a large population living on the 
brink of poverty; and (iii) new manifestations of urban poverty. Without dramatic improvements, the PRC might not achieve 
MDG targets for gender equity, environmental sustainability, child mortality, HIV/AIDS, and access to safe drinking water and 
sanitation. 
 
Experience in the PRC shows that poverty is both a cause and effect of environmental degradation. The poor, lacking the daily 
necessities and basic means of livelihood, are forced to overexploit often fragile ecosystems. On the other hand, the poor have 
often to bear disproportionate impacts of ecological degradation. A sustainable development strategy has been included in the 
11th Five-Year Plan (2006–2010), which emphasizes a “resource-efficient and environment-friendly, harmonious society” by 
maintaining a balance between economic growth, socioeconomic development, and environmental protection. The plan sets 
forth a series of environmental targets for urban environmental improvement, ecosystem rehabilitation, natural resources 
management, and mitigating natural disasters. 
 
The CPS (2008–2010) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for the PRC emphasizes continued support to reduce poverty, 
improve the quality of life for the millions of people with low incomes, and assist the PRC in making its contribution to protect 
regional and global public goods. The Project supports ADB’s strategic concerns to improve the environment and promote 
equitable and inclusive growth, as set out in the strategy. Nationally, poor people mostly live in the central and western 
provinces that lag the eastern provinces in achieving MDGs. In these regions, poverty is mostly rural and strongly correlated 
with access to land and incidence of land degradation. The Project will address poverty reduction by introducing ecologically- 
sound investments that support the livelihoods of the rural poor by supporting them in obtaining better access to higher-value 
market  chains  and  off-farm  income;  improving  vocational  skills;  and  reducing  vulnerability  through  contract  farming 
arrangements that include provision of technical, financial, and marketing skills.  
 
The poverty partnership agreement, signed by the Government and ADB in September 2003, sets out strategies and 
interventions for poverty reduction. The PRC and ADB will cooperate on a broad range of activities related to policy and 
regulatory reform and capacity building in the environment sector. They will support projects to reduce poverty as one of the 
underlying causes of environmental problems. Projects will be designed so that the poor increase their incomes while also 
capturing environmental benefits. The proposed Project will support the Government’s efforts by tackling the root causes of 
poverty through promoting an integrated water resources management approach that will lead to increased water use 
efficiencies. In this way, it will contribute to achieving MDGs relating to environmental sustainability (MDG7). Specific 
interventions such as watershed rehabilitation and better allocation of water resources without wastage contribute to this. 
Through providing a safe and assured water supply for irrigation purposes for the beneficiary communities, the Project will 
have a direct impact on improving livelihoods in poor farming communities. This will be achieved by directly boosting incomes 
through higher crop productivity and increased yields and cropping intensity.

Qinghai is the headwaters for the Yangtze and Yellow rivers. Being mountainous, it has a small population and a large land 
area. The bulk of the 5.38 million population lives in rural areas. Its population includes Tibetan, Mongolian, Hui, Tu, Sala, 
Kazak, and other minority nationalities. Qinghai has sustained a high rate of economic growth since 2000. Its gross domestic 
product grew by 12.2% annually over 2000–2004. As a whole, however, the province is still one of the poorest in the PRC and 
comprises  a  total  of  15  nationally-designated  poor  counties.  The  per  capita  net  income  and  per  capita  consumption 
expenditure of farmers in Qinghai in 2004 was about two thirds of the national average.  
 
The ratio of income for the bottom 20% households to the provincial average declined from 35.3% to 34.2% in 2004. The 
incidence of rural poverty as measured by poverty line and low-income line was 19.94% and 37.7%, respectively, in 2004. 
Apart from income poverty, Qinghai is also very poor as measured by such non-income indicators as education, access to safe 
drinking water, access to health services, and owned assets. In spite of notable attempts by the Government to reduce poverty, 
Qinghai as a whole is unlikely to be able to meet its targets for poverty reduction by 2010. 
 
The proposed Project is in line with the ADB CPS goals to (i) support environmental improvement, (ii) reverse natural resource 
degradation, (iii) address water resource depletion and livelihood improvements for people residing in threatened and sensitive 
areas, and (iv) encourage rural development and infrastructure such as irrigation and water management. The proposed 
Project indirectly supports CPS aims by attempting to improve access to agricultural markets for farms and private agro-
enterprises and providing employment opportunities in disadvantaged and poverty-stricken areas. The three counties were 
designated as national poverty counties and in need of immediate attention. This need is clearly indicated in the data for rural 
poverty incidence: 51% in Jianzha, 53% in Hualong, and 61% in Xunhua (using CNY800 per capita per year as a threshold). In 
the proposed project area (irrigation command area), the poverty incidence is 47%. The poverty incidence in the project area 
by ethnic group is as follows: 40% for the Han, 52% for the Hui, 33% for the Sala, and 35% for the Tibetans. Clearly, poverty is 
widespread among all groups. Preliminary project interventions, as described in the CPS, will also seek to strengthen provincial 
and county government capacity and empowerment of rural communities through capacity building and training support. 
Interventions  will  simultaneously  help  increase  the  efficiency  of  government  support  services,  including  research  and 
extension.  
 
The Project aims at alleviating poverty and improving the livelihoods of poor rural farming households by rehabilitating and 
constructing key irrigation infrastructure in the three counties of Hualong, Jianza, and Xunhua situated in the northeastern part 
of Qinghai Province. The three project counties have a rural population of 370,000, of which an estimated 154,000 will benefit 
from the Project. The ethnic minority population breakdown of the project beneficiaries is as follows: 43% are Sala, 34% are 
Hui, 13% are Tibetan, 6% are Han, and 4% are others (mainly Tu). The Project will especially benefit the Sala, a small Muslim 
group that are mainly located in Xunhua County; in fact, more than half of all Sala people will be among the beneficiaries. 
 
B.  Targeting Classification  
         
1.  Select the targeting classification of the Project: 
 
 General Intervention    Individual or Household (TI-H)  Geographic (TI-G)  Non-Income MDGs (TI-M1, M2, etc.) 
 
2.    Explain the basis for the targeting classification:  
 
The Project will cover three counties of Qinghai Province and subprojects which will seek to improve irrigated agriculture and 
water resources management in the project area. The direct benefits to be accrued from this work will be an overall increase in 
agricultural productivity and resulting gains for the farming communities. The farmers will further benefit from reduced wastage 
of water and water logging, improved drainage, and significantly increased irrigation opportunities. Since local labor for the 
construction activities will be pooled directly from the project site, there will be a concomitant benefit for poor and vulnerable 
groups able to take advantage of these additional employment opportunities. 
 
The Project will also have a direct impact at the household level, as it will afford increased incomes and employment 
opportunities by providing a steady and ensured water supply for irrigation purposes. At present, lack of water is the main 
constraint farmers face with regard to farming. The Project will directly address this constraint and, in the process, heightened 
income levels will be noted at the household level.  
 
C.  Poverty Analysis 
 
   
1.   If the Project is classified as TI-H, or if it is policy-based, what type of poverty impact analysis is needed?  
 
Basic poverty and social analysis is proposed. The technical assistance (TA) will assess the incidence of poverty using existing 
data sources, supplemented by a social survey of project beneficiaries. Both income and non-income poverty indexes will be

be given to (i) profiling the beneficiaries, including by ethnic and gender disaggregation, as well as by economic and social

2.  What resources are allocated in the project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA)/due diligence? 
 
The PPTA will allocate resources to hire the services of a social and poverty specialist and gender specialist who will assist in 
further refining the pro-poor features of the proposed works.  
 
3.  If GI, is there any opportunity for pro-poor design (e.g., social inclusion subcomponents, cross-subsidy, pro-poor 
governance, and pro-poor growth)? 
 
The farmers would be targeted by providing them with a cheaper water supply, extension services for cash crops and 
marketing. The local poor will benefit as laborers, because increased coverage and additional cropping will create additional 
employment opportunities in the agricultural sector. Opportunities for providing microcredit will be investigated during the TA 
work. Moreover, there  will  be direct benefits from employment opportunities afforded to local  communities during the 
construction works. 
 
II.  SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT ISSUES 
 
A.   Initial Social Analysis 
 
Based on existing information: 
 
1.  Who are the potential primary beneficiaries of the Project? How do the poor and the socially excluded benefit from the 
Project?  
 
From the outset, the Project will improve agricultural production through integrated irrigated agriculture and water resources 
management. This will directly benefit entire communities engaged in agricultural activities and, in particular, the Hui and Sala 
ethnic minority groups. Farmers at all levels in the three counties (large, small, medium, and marginal) will benefit from higher 
agricultural productivity and increased agricultural coverage as a direct result of increased irrigation opportunities. In addition to 
their involvement with the construction works, poor men and women will benefit from direct livelihood and employment 
opportunities and skills transfer created as part of the Project and with additional TA funds. The most significant gains will be 
through increased employment afforded by opportunities in the agricultural sectors. 
 
2.  What are the potential needs of beneficiaries in relation to the proposed Project?  
 
At present, subproject beneficiaries suffer directly from a lack of irrigation opportunities, and cropping intensity is low as the 
costs of water and electricity associated with farming are unaffordable. Water conservation and command area development 
are basic needs for the communities living in the subproject area and ones that the Project will seek to meet. In overall terms, 
the poor need employment opportunities, access to capital, and productive skills for livelihood support. 
 
3.  What are the potential constraints in accessing the proposed benefits and services, and how will the Project address 
them?  
 
At present, beneficiary communities are unable to finance water management infrastructure. The Project will meet this need 
and will construct the infrastructure necessary for command area development, water conservation, and improved irrigation 
facilities. The Executing Agency (EA) has limited capacity to manage participatory water conservation and improve irrigation 
facilities. Similarly, the project beneficiaries have not previously been exposed to community-based participatory methods of 
engagement. Thus, there is a strong need for capacity building in this area. The Project will directly address this gap by 
supporting inclusiveness and promoting a situation where all beneficiary groups can participate and access benefits from 
project activities. Linkages between service-providing departments in allied sectors will be sought so that beneficiaries can 
access resources, training, and capital. Technical assistance will be given to strengthen the EA’s capacity to facilitate and 
manage participatory processes in integrated irrigated agriculture and water resources management.

B.   Consultation and Participation 
 
1.   Indicate the potential initial stakeholders. 
  
Primary stakeholders within the Government include the Ministry of Finance, National Development Reform Commission, and 
Ministry of Water Resources. At the provincial level, the EA will be the Qinghai Provincial Department of Water Resources. 
Other key stakeholders include the Provincial National Development and Reform Commission. At the subproject level, 
stakeholders will include farmers and such relevant service-providing agencies as the Department of Environment, and 
Agriculture Extension, which will be responsible for providing extension support services to the subproject beneficiaries. 
 
2.   What type of consultation and participation (C&P) is required during the TA or project processing (e.g., workshops, 
community mobilization, and involvement of nongovernment organizations and community-based organizations)? 
 
Consultation (e.g., interviews and/or focus groups) and workshops will be the primary methods adopted for social, gender, and 
environmental assessments and for developing action plans and methodologies. In addition to the requisite inception, midterm, 
and final workshops, there will be consultations seeking to strengthen participatory subproject development and enhance 
linkages with associated government line departments to improve support services provision. 
 
3.  What level of participation is envisaged for project design? 
     Information sharing          Consultation         Collaborative decision making         Empowerment 
 
An ethnic minority development plan will be prepared and will emphasize participation. 
 
4.  Will a C&P plan be prepared?    Yes          No    Please explain.  
 
An effective, practical, and inclusive participation strategy will be developed based on a thorough assessment of the needs and 
interests of all the represented groups. Means to strengthen the linkages and cooperation with service-providing agencies and 
the union council will be pursued to ensure that the benefits from the project interventions are maximized.  
 
C.  Gender and Development 
 
1.  What are the key gender issues in the sector and/or subsector that are likely to be relevant to this project/program? 
 
Even though women are involved in agricultural activities, their contribution in that area may not be considered important. 
Moreover, women bear the gravest burden of poverty in the project area and are among the most vulnerable in times of 
disaster. Thus, they need the most support for coping with such events. This is perhaps best demonstrated in instances where 
male household heads are no longer present and the burden of looking after those households is left with the female heads of 
households. With limited education and the need to be present at home, they may bear the brunt of poverty’s burdens. 
 
2.    Does the proposed project/program have the potential to promote gender equality and/or women’s empowerment by 
improving women’s access to and use of opportunities, services, resources, assets, and participation in decision 
making?       Yes          No    Please explain.  
 
The Project presents a unique opportunity to promote women’s empowerment by facilitating their access to employment, skills, 
and other resources. The TA will focus on assessing useful models for integrating gender aspects into the project interventions. 
As the Project will benefit the agricultural landholders, it will particularly target women as beneficiaries through specific 
components and initiatives. It will also seek to encourage employment and income-earning opportunities in the production 
sector that will benefit the Project. A comprehensive gender action plan, adequately resourced, will be prepared during the TA 
and its findings integrated into the ethnic minority development plan. 
 
3.   Could the proposed project have an adverse impact on women and/or girls or to widen gender inequality?        
        Yes          No    Please explain. 
 
Increased farm productivity from improved irrigation and related processing will enable women to contribute a larger share of 
household incomes compared to that from the subsistence farming they do now.

(ii)  Provide  technical  support  to  the  EA  and  IAs  in  developing  reports,  review 
procedures, public consultations and disclosures, and environmental management 
plans.  
(iii)  Submit  EIA  and/or  IEE  write-ups  evaluating  the  environmental  viability  and 
sustainability of the subprojects and Project as a whole and identify environmental 
considerations that may form part of the loan covenants.  
(iv)  Provide indicators for the project performance monitoring system.  
(v)  Assist the team leader and deputy team leader in preparing various relevant reports.

Appendix 4   19
 
10.  Institutional and Community Development Specialist (3 person-months). The specialist 
will:  
 
(i)  Review and assess the social analyses in the FSRs prepared by the EA.  
(ii)  Conduct any supplementary studies to update and improve the social analyses. 
(iii)  Review and assess the social impacts of the project interventions and prepare 
possible mitigation measures in accordance with ADB guidelines. 
(iv)  Prepare  socioeconomic  and  poverty  profiles  for  the  project  area  by  collecting 
information through statistical records, field surveys, and key informant interviews. 
(v)  Analyze data by gender, ethnic group, town, and urban versus rural setting to 
provide a comprehensive baseline profile of socioeconomic conditions of affected 
and/or beneficiary project areas.  
(vi)  Use a participatory approach to involve stakeholders from the municipal and county 
levels, as well as potential beneficiaries in the analysis and design of the Project. 
(vii)  Propose a community development plan to be included in the Project.  
(viii)  Conduct workshops with stakeholders at municipal, county, district, and/or township 
levels to discuss the proposed irrigation design schemes and other relevant project 
design issues in a participatory manner, then prepare a recommended plan that 
includes establishing WUAs for participatory O&M of those irrigation schemes to be 
undertaken.  
(ix)  Prepare relevant sections of reports for the team leader. 
 
11.  Agricultural Extension Specialist (3 person-months). The specialist will:  
 
(i)  Assess  the  performance  of  various  irrigated  agriculture  developments  and 
synthesize lessons and good practices.  
(ii)  Review,  assess,  and  synthesize  key  technical  and  other  constraints,  marketing 
prospects,  and  farmer  incentives  for  intensified  and  diversified  cropping  in  the 
project area.  
(iii)  Support  preparation  of  the  irrigated  agriculture  development  strategy,  including 
options for delivering more effective, responsive, and sustainable extension systems 
to WUAs.  
(iv)  Identify options and strategies for (a) using an alternative extension approach (such 
as  private  providers  or  research  institutions),  (b)  using  WUAs  to  address 
complementary farm activities, and (c) effective linkages with research institutions 
and the like. 
(v)  Assist  in  collecting  data,  analyzing  constraints,  and  estimating  realistically 
achievable cropping patterns and yields; design effective agricultural activities that 
include extension arrangements and promote command area development works; 
and propose the final arrangements and programs for project management and 
institutional strengthening.
